item.title: The Biggest Magic: The Gathering Crashers and Climbers This Week - August 18
item.content:encoded:
The Magic: The Gathering train rumbles on, with preorders going live last week for Avatar: The Last Airbender, and hype building for Spider-Man next month, but Edge of Eternities is already seeing some big changes in value.

That’s not all, though. A Foundations staple and a card two decades old are getting some love, while Final Fantasy’s Vivi Ornitier is going nowhere, it seems. Here are this week’s crashers and climbers, thanks to data from TCGPlayer.

New Foundation

Let’s kick things off with a card that’s pretty easy to find. Soulstone Sanctuary, printed in last year’s Foundations set, has essentially doubled in value.

Magic: The Gathering Soulstone Sanctuary

It’s a land that can become a 3/3 creature, but that creature is all types. That means that if your opponent goes for the Shoot the Sheriff (a low-cost removal spell), it won’t be able to remove Soulstone Sanctuary since it’s essentially an Assassin, Mercenary, Pirate, Rogue, and Warlock all in one.

Magic: The Gathering Masako the Humorless

Next? Masako the Humorless was printed way back in Champions of Kamigawa, and she’s a low-cost creature that can be played at instant speed thanks to the flash keyword, allowing your untapped cards to block.

That’s great, but why is she so popular now? Well, it’s because you can tap all your creatures to station one of the new spacecraft card types in Edge of Eternities, safe in the knowledge that they can still block thanks to Masako.

Magic: The Gathering Vivi Ornitier

Unsurprisingly, we’re also talking about Final Fantasy’s Vivi Ornitier again. He’s been tearing up just about any competition in recent months, and while he started to drop in value, he’s back in vogue after a string of competitive appearances.

We’re seeing him back to around $60 in market value, and I’m STILL trying to find time to build a spellslinger deck around him.

Magic: The Gathering Agatha's Soul Cauldron

He pairs very nicely with Agatha’s Soul Cauldron from Wilds of Eldraine, and it’s still being sold for around $70. Its market value is lower, though, at around $55.

Magic: The Gathering Winternight Stories

Finally, Winternight Stories is a recent release (from Tarkir: Dragonstorm) that gets Vivi into the graveyard so that the Soul Cauldron can exile it, thereby turning any creature with a counter into another Vivi.

It’s still cheap at around $2, but as its value is becoming clearer, expect it to shuffle higher. Buy low, as they say.

Life Is A Stage

More Edge of Eternities drop-offs this week, as expected. For one, this lovely borderless treatment of Thespian’s Stage is down to $2 but is selling for less.

Magic: The Gathering Thespian's Stage

If you fancy pulling off the Thespian’s Stage/Dark Depths combo to cheat out a 20/20 monstrosity, this is a nice printing to do it with.

Wizards of The Coast - Magic: The Gathering Edge of Eternities Commander Deck - World Shaper

I maintain it’s a perfect addition to the World Shaper precon, and its market value has dropped below $20 now. Expect it to go down further in the coming weeks.

Magic: The Gathering Tezzeret, Cruel Captain

Another popular card is Tezzeret, Cruel Captain. This Planeswalker has dropped from $70 at the set’s launch down to just shy of $30. I’d be very surprised if it doesn’t get lower week by week now.

Magic: The Gathering Uthros, Titanic Godcore

Uthros, Titanic Godcore has just hit a low of $18.54, having been in the high $40 range around launch, and can be a late-game powerhouse for blue decks.

Magic: The Gathering Yuna, Hope of Spira

We’ll end this section today with Yuna, Hope of Spira. This Final Fantasy card is starting to drop, now at around the $10 mark. Expect it to get lower, too.

A Future Climber?

Magic: The Gathering Redirect Lightning

One card that’s caught the eye of Commander deckbuilders from the upcoming Avatar set is Redirect Lighting. As the name suggests, it’ll turn a spell or ability from one target onto another.

It’s not quite as powerful as Deflecting Swat, but it’s still likely to be very popular later this year. Plus, that card is $50!

Magic: The Gathering Deflecting Swat

But that's not the only Magic deals worth discussing today, and arguably the best deal of the week is still the MTG x Final Fantasy precons bundle. It's down to $189.99 at Amazon, $90 off the MSRP, and the best price we've ever seen for the four commander deck set.

That’s less than $50 a deck, despite three out of four costing more than that when bought separately. In fact, Final Fantasy 7’s Limit Break is STILL $72.50 at Amazon.

Final Fantasy - Commander Deck Bundle

Amazon has also just launched one of the best Magic: The Gathering deals of the year today, heavily discounting the stylish MTG Aetherdrift Finish Line Bundle for a limited time. Usually priced at $79.99, it's on a hot lap discount and dropped to its lowest price yet at $52.70.

Staying in theme with its racing roots, this bundle is selling fast, as Magic fans are snapping up the discount as quickly as they can. And it's clear why, as this deal is even better than the one we saw a few months back during a similar Amazon sale, where it hovered around $60 for a short time.

Aetherdrift Finish Line Bundle

Limited stock available. When it's gone, it's gone!

Lloyd Coombes is an experienced freelancer in tech, gaming and fitness seen at Polygon, Eurogamer, Macworld, TechRadar and many more. He's a big fan of Magic: The Gathering and other collectible card games, much to his wife's dismay.

Originally posted:

Aug 18, 2025 8:00 pm

item.title: Oh Boy, Geoff Keighley Is Teasing Hollow Knight: Silksong for Gamescom Opening Night Live
item.content:encoded:
Beware of what you're about to unleash.

Uh oh, Geoff Keighley is teasing Hollow Knight: Silksong at Gamescom Opening Night Live. Is it...finally time? Dare we hope?

— Geoff Keighley (@geoffkeighley) August 18, 2025

If that above post means nothing to you, you've managed to steer clear of the Hollow Knight: Silksong fervor for years now, somehow. Since 2021, Hollow Knight fans have used images and emojis of clowns (and specifically, the one right below) to goof about their constant hope for news about Silksong, especially around big presentations like Nintendo Directs, The Game Awards, or Summer Game Fest. Every time a new presentation rolled around, Silksong fans would post clown images and joke about putting on clown makeup, effectively acknowledging that it was cartoonish to hope for Silksong news but that they were hoping anyway.

Of course, Keighley could just be posting himself in a clown outfit for the heck of it, but I can't imagine that would be advisable given the fervor of the Silksong audience. Earlier this year, fans went nuts over a chocolate cake recipe, in a move which went so far as to force the developers to make a statement, so teasing that audience probably isn't the best idea.

Still, Keighley's tease seems like a pretty sure thing. We know Silksong is coming out in 2025 barring any unexpected delays, and there's a demo of the game playable on the show floor of Gamescom this week. We also know, via a leak, that the ROG Xbox Ally will launch on October 16, and Xbox's Sarah Bond has previously stated that Silksong would be on the system when it launched. If everyone's telling the truth and there have been no last-minute changes, that means Silksong should be out in the next two months sometime. And that would also mean we're due for an actual, real, confirmed release date any second now. Who's got a big showcase going on where such an announcement would make a huge splash? Keighley, of course.

Now, there's always a chance that we're all just putting on our clown makeup today only to be disappointed once again tomorrow. Grab a slice of chocolate cake, stick on that rubber nose, and let's lock in for Opening Night Live tomorrow. Silksong silksoon?

Rebekah Valentine is a senior reporter for IGN. You can find her posting on BlueSky @duckvalentine.bsky.social. Got a story tip? Send it to rvalentine@ign.com.

In This Article

item.title: The 10 Most Valuable Journey Together Pokémon Cards That I'm Still Chasing In Sealed Boosters
item.content:encoded:
The Journey Together set (also known as SV09) feels like one of the most collector-driven Pokémon TCG expansions in recent memory. That’s thanks to its blending of fan-favourite characters, nostalgic Trainer-Pokémon duos, and gorgeous cinematic artwork to top them off.

It has captivated both players and collectors, and while it hasn’t shaken up the competitive meta dramatically, its cards — particularly those featuring notable figures like Lillie, N, and Iono — have brought in some notable market values.

TL;DR – 10 Valuable Pokémon TCG Cards From the Journey Together Set

With Journey Together being one of many Pokémon sets in short supply (following Destined Rivals, Prismatic Evolutions, Black Bolt, and White Flare), their high prices through retailers like TCGplayer or eBay will likely stay higher for the foreseeable future.

Thanks to the data available, we’ve looked at the 10 most valuable Journey Together Pokémon cards on TCGplayer — and gone through what they’re currently worth, why that’s the case, and links to grab your own right now.

10. N’s Reshiram – 167/159 (Illustration Rare)

N's Reshiram - 167/159

Despite modest power on the battlefield, N’s Reshiram is a stunner visually. The dreamy art style sets it apart, with pastel tones that blend N’s iconic soft-spoken nature with Reshiram’s divine presence — almost making it look like the cover of a fairy tale. Its main value stems from character appeal, not competitive strength — but it’s already seeing a slow rise in demand from collectors.

9. Iono’s Bellibolt ex – 188/159 (Hyper Rare)

Iono's Bellibolt ex - 188/159

This golden Hyper Rare is more than eye candy, since the Electric Streamer ability of Iono’s Bellibolt ex provides reliable Lightning energy acceleration, making it useful in niche Electric decks. While not a meta staple, Iono’s popularity continues to push her cards into collectors’ crosshairs.

8. N’s Zoroark ex – 189/159 (Hyper Rare)

N's Zoroark ex - 189/159

N returns once again with a sleek Zoroark. Like its Special Illustration Rare counterpart, this card has Trade, one of the strongest card draw abilities in the game. With its golden finish and historical relevance to classic Zoroark GX decks, this is a solid budget-friendly option for players and collectors alike.

7. Articuno – 161/159 (Illustration Rare)

Articuno - 161/159

This Illustration Rare version of Articuno brings a stunning frozen aesthetic to match its sharp blue colouring, blending a simultaneous sense of camouflage and elegance. As for gameplay, Frigid Fluttering offers decent early-game acceleration in Water decks, but it’s the artwork that carries the value here.

If you’re a fan of the original legendary bird trio, this is a must-have.

6. Volcanion ex – 182/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

Volcanion ex - 182/159

With Akagi behind the brush to bring back their striking art style, it’s no surprise this card is climbing in value. While Volcanion ex’s Scalding Steam ability and respectable attack make it a fine tech in some fire decks, its illustration’s dynamic and powerful tones make for one of the most visually aggressive cards in the set.

5. Hop’s Zacian ex – 186/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

Hop's Zacian ex - 186/159

Zacian continues its streak as a playable and collectable legend. This version, partnered with Hop, features a charming and relaxing forest scene, which comes off as an interesting tonal shift from previous Zacian cards.

Hop's Zacian ex is still testing its footing competitively, as well, but fans of Galar’s rivals with the cash to spare will likely scoop this one up based on narrative and nostalgia alone.

4. N’s Zoroark ex – 185/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

N's Zoroark ex - 185/159

Like its Hyper Rare equivalent, this SIR version of N’s Zoroark ex is one of the most competitively viable cards in the set. Trade is still an exceptional ability, but its slick artwork doubles the appeal, with N and Zoroark standing ominously under a moody spotlight.

Still, with this one’s much higher value, we’d recommend keeping this version of N’s Zoroark in your folder if you have one of the cheaper versions for your deck.

3. Iono’s Bellibolt ex – 183/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

Iono's Bellibolt ex - 183/159

As with many Iono cards, demand is high across the board, and this delightful SIR Bellibolt card offers the same Electric Streamer utility as its Hyper Rare with a highly animated, stylised background, and adorable close-up featuring the Scarlet & Violet gym leader and her partner Pokémon.

While not dominating tournaments, the sheer popularity of Iono’s character continues to make this Iono's Bellibolt ex card one of the most sought-after from the set.

2. Salamence ex – 187/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

Salamence ex - 187/159

This Salamence ex card captures everything fans love about the pseudo-legendary with its big power, bold colours, and imposing presence. It’s not the most practical card in the meta due to its high energy costs, but its nostalgic pull and sweeping museum-grade artwork have given it a big lift in value.

1. Lillie’s Clefairy ex – 184/159 (Special Illustration Rare)

Lillie's Clefairy ex - 184/159

The Journey Together set’s crown jewel in price is, unsurprisingly, a Lillie card with a $125+ value at the time of writing. Her Special Illustration Rare Clefairy ex is both a gorgeous bit of scenery between Trainer and adorable Pocket Monster, and is a competent card in its own right, by scaling its attack with the number of Benched Pokémon.

That said, it’s the soft glow of the field, the cute story it paints with its artwork, and Lillie’s high popularity that vault this card to the top of the value chart.

Ben Williams – IGN freelance contributor with over 10 years of experience covering gaming, tech, film, TV, and anime. Follow him on Twitter/X @BenLevelTen.
